awd_titl_txt: Self-Coordination of Dyneins during Ciliary Beating
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanism of self-coordinated oscillations of motile cilia.  Motile cilia are whip-like structures that protrude like bristles from the cell surface and generate a periodic beating waveform.  Ciliary beating powers the swimming of sperm and many small organisms. Ciliary beating also generates fluid flow in the intestines and lungs, and mediates cell signaling.  The core structural component of a cilium is the axoneme, which has a ring of nine outer microtubule doublets surrounding two central microtubules.  A detailed investigation of the mechanism that powers self-coordinated ciliary beating will significantly contribute to our understanding of how ciliary malfunction is linked to a group of defects known as ciliopathies.  The Broader Impacts of this Project will also help establish educational outreach programs for high school students from underrepresented groups in Oakland, CA.  To attract a new generation to science, summer research opportunities, seminars and science fairs will be organized in local public schools. Undergraduate students will contribute to the Project by actively participating in the research. The results of the proposed research will be integrated into a new curriculum that will be developed for Physics undergraduates wishing to pursue a graduate career in the life sciences.

The basic principle of ciliary beating relies on a sliding motion between microtubules and two different types of dynein motor proteins, the inner arm and the outer arm dyneins.  To bend microtubules locally in cilia, dyneins on one side of an axoneme must be active while those on the opposite side are inactive.  These states must switch periodically to propagate bending along the length of the axoneme.  The negative feedback mechanisms that coordinate the activities of dynein motors across an axoneme remain to be determined.  To elucidate the mechanisms that regulate ciliary beating, this project will test several predictions for the mechanical properties of Tetrahymena inner- and outer-arm dyneins in vitro.  Using single-molecule fluorescence and manipulation methods, the project will complete three goals.  It will determine the mechanism by which dynein monomers step relative to each other as the motor slides microtubule filaments.  It will investigate the emergent properties of dynein motors when functioning in large teams.  The project will also reconstitute a minimal system for ciliary oscillations and visualize the movement of individual microtubules.  The successful completion of this project will reveal new molecular mechanisms of inner-arm and outer-arm dynein coordination and determine minimum requirements for self-coordinated oscillations of motile cilia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dyneins are a family of motor proteins that carry out motility and force generation functions towards the minus end of microtubule filaments. Cytoplasmic dynein (dynein-1) is responsible for transporting intracellular cargos in the retrograde direction in the cytoplasm. All other dyneins are localized to cilia, a microtubule-rich organelle that protrudes from the cell body like bristles. The core structural component of cilia is the axoneme, which is composed of nine microtubule doublets arranged in a circle, surrounding a central pair of single microtubules. Axonemal dyneins are positioned between adjacent microtubule doublets of the axoneme and power ciliary beating by sliding microtubules relative to each other. To bend microtubules locally, dyneins on one side of an axoneme must be active while those on the other side are inactive. Theoretical studies proposed that dynein activity may be coordinated by the changes in microtubule curvature during bending. However, it remains unclear whether dyneins could sense small strains associated with observed microtubule curvature (0.5 µm-1), which is two orders of magnitude larger than the dimension of a tubulin dimer.

 Recently, a tagged, full-length outer arm dynein (OAD) gene was recombinantly expressed in Tetrahymena for the first time. We used this system to test the curvature-control model by generating surfaces that are similar to ciliary waveforms at the desired curvature. We performed microtubule sliding assays on these surfaces and measured the binding affinity, velocity, directionality, and processivity of single and multiple OADs depending on the direction of the microtubule bend as well as its sharpness. The microtubule gliding velocity of OAD decreased by microtubule curvature and when the radius of curvature reached 2 µm, which matches that of the maximum curvature of beating cilia. The dynein motors facing both the stretched and compressed surfaces of microtubules exhibit similar defects in motility, suggesting that curvature does not create asymmetric control of dynein motors. Our all-atom MD simulations also showed that curvature does not directly affect the MT binding of dynein to microtubules. Collectively, our results are inconsistent with the change in microtubule curvature in bent cilium to control dyneins, and support models in which contacts between dyneins in an array and other axonemal components to control sliding activities of dynein motors during ciliary beating.

We also studied how human dynein-1 is activated and regulated to ensure appropriate cargo transport. Mutations in dynein regulators are linked to neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases such as lissencephaly (due to mutations in the gene that encodes LIS1) and microcephaly (due to mutations in the gene that encodes Ndel1). When not transporting cargo, dynein-1 is autoinhibited by self-dimerization of its motor domains. We showed that a dynein-associated factor LIS1 promotes the release of dynein from its autoinhibited conformation, and thus facilitates the formation of active dynein-dynactin complexes. Ndel1 interfaces with LIS1 to impact dynein function, but its precise molecular roles in the dynein pathway remained unknown. We investigated how Ndel1 (together with Lis1) regulates the assembly and activation of the dynein/dynactin/adaptor complexes in vitro, thus providing a long-anticipated mechanistic cue about the physiological function of this key regulatory protein. We showed that Ndel1 promotes the assembly of active dynein complexes by recruiting LIS1 to dynein. Nde1 promotes dynein motility by 1) competing with the inhibitor of LIS1, PAFAH-α2 by binding to the Lis1 beta-propeller domain and 2) binding to the dynein intermediate chain in the autoinhibited conformation of dynein and positioning Lis1 near its dynein binding site (which is inaccessible in the autoinhibited conformation of dynein). Nde1 binds to the same site where the p150 subunit of dynactin interacts with the dynein intermediate chain. Dynactin binding releases Nde1 and subsequently Lis1 from dynein, providing an explanation for why Lis1/Nde1 is only needed for the activation of dynein machinery but not for subsequent motility. These results significantly advanced our understanding of how cells control the activation and inhibition of the dynein transport machinery.

The PI has also incorporated various educational activities into his research. Yildiz Laboratory hosted a total of 12 undergraduate students and 6 high school students, most of which were accepted to prestigious B.S. and Ph.D.  programs and 3 of them received NSF graduate fellowships. The PI serves as the chair of the Biophysics Graduate Group at UC Berkeley. He initiated a diversity equity and inclusion (DEI) committee and revised the curriculum and graduation requirements to ensure that all students receive the mentoring and training they would need to be successful in this program. The PI is also the co-director of the Biophysics Training Grant at UC Berkeley in order to train next-generation scientists at the interface of physics and biology. They develop new courses, run monthly luncheons and seminars, and develop new strategies to increase the representation of students from underprivileged and underrepresented groups in science.
